p: Traditionally, influenza vaccines are produced by generating a natural or recombinant reassortant IAV expressing the immunogenic HA antigen [ 14, 32]. The IAV comprises of two subunits HA1 and HA2, hosting the antigenic sites to which specific and neutralizing antibodies are elicited to combat IAVs strains during vaccination or natural infection [ 14, 33]. However, it was reported that the specificity of the vaccine produced in cell-culture and embryonated eggs is occasionally impaired by amino acid (aa) changes, due to seed strain adaptation, with a drastic impact on vaccine effectiveness [ 14, 15, 16]. The vaccine platform presented in this study depends on plasmid-based bacterial expression of recombinant viral antigen(s). These plasmids, encoding viral antigen(s), can be easily and quickly modified to insert non-synonymous changes in the encoding region of the antigen(s). Additionally, the bacterial expression has lower mutation rates than eukaryotes [ 34]. This platform can be also a base for incorporating combinations of different viral antigens to address additional vaccines needed to combat seasonal H1N1, H3N2 and influenza B viruses.
